Award.AwardTitle: AF: Small: Metric Information Theory, Online Learning, and Competitive Analysis

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: There will always be limitations on human ability to collect and process data<br/>about systems, environments, and populations. Algorithmic agents act in real<br/>time based on partial, noisy information about the world, and the elimination<br/>of uncertainty through "learning" must often be balanced against the<br/>optimization of some objective. The cost of choices made in the present must<br/>be weighed against the risk that those choices might incur further costs in<br/>the future. Information theory provides a rich and fertile framework for quantifying and<br/>managing uncertainty. The situation becomes more subtle when distinct pieces<br/>of information carry differing costs. Consider one's 401(k) balance at<br/>retirement. While the least significant digit is most uncertain, there is<br/>substantially more cost associated with incorrectly predicting the value of the<br/>most significant digit.<br/><br/>This project concerns probability spaces endowed with a metric that describes<br/>the associated cost of uncertainty. Designing algorithms to optimize in such a<br/>framework is intimately connected to having a robust theory of metric<br/>information. Moreover, the settings of online optimization and competitive<br/>analysis provide a deep and varied set of formal models in which to apply these<br/>methods and test their efficacy. In an area where algorithm design and <br/>analysis have often been seen as ad-hoc and unstructured, the framework <br/>underlying this work contends that both algorithms and their analysis can be<br/>derived readily from the right set of underlying definitions. Indeed, many <br/>problems in this area have been researched for 30-40 years, and<br/>yet preliminary application of algorithms and analysis tools from online convex<br/>optimization--in the context of metric probability spaces--has already achieved<br/>a sequence of breakthroughs. The team of researchers will develop the <br/>corresponding theory, guided by a collection of prominent open problems, with<br/>the ultimate goal of understanding in what circumstances, and to what extent, <br/>one can limit the detrimental effects of uncertainty on optimization.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
